Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \\) applied to an initial complex number \\( z_0 \\), within a system governed by the linear differential operator \\( L(z) = \frac{d^2z}{dt^2} + \omega^2 z \\). Analyze the impact of the integral transformation defined by \\( T(z) = \int e^{-i\omega t} z(t) dt \\), where \\( \omega \\) is a constant.

If \\( T(z) \\) is applied to \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0 and then allowed to evolve under \\( L(z) \\) without further intervention, will the outcome at a later time T be equivalent to directly evolving \\( z_0 \\) under \\( L(z) \\)?
Explanation: The integral transformation \\( T(z) \\) fundamentally alters the initial condition from a single complex number to a function of time, thus changing the dynamic response of the system under the differential operator \\( L(z) \\). This evolution will not correspond to the simple evolution of \\( z_0 \\) under \\( L(z) \\), because the transformation introduces an integration that dissipates the initial conditions over time.
